;在美国流行文化中，成年往往是一个人的努力。青春期是我们开始根据父母、同龄人和构建我们世界的力量来定义自己的时候；好莱坞经常将争夺身份的斗争提炼成孤独英雄的旅程。但是，对于 FX 电视剧《保留狗》的核心人物来说，这本质上是一种公共体验，该剧刚刚结束了在 Hulu 上的三季播出。早些时候，四人组——贝尔（法老王 Woon-A-Tai 饰）、埃洛拉（德弗里·雅各布斯饰）、奶酪（莱恩·法因特饰）和威利·杰克（宝琳娜·亚历克西斯饰）——抵制这一揭露，坚信他们的家乡奥肯，俄克拉荷马州杀死了他们小组的第五名成员丹尼尔（道尔顿克莱默饰），他梦想着放弃他们的马斯科吉住宅前往加利福尼亚海滩。朋友自杀一年后，青少年们为他的朋友感到悲痛，他们看不到观众能看到什么：那个尘土飞扬的奥肯还活着，有古怪的人、艺术家、帮助者和治愈的方法。剧集主管斯特林·哈乔 (Sterlin Harjo) 与塔伊卡·维迪提 (Taika Waititi) 共同创作了该剧，并在接下来的两季中继续扩展这种马赛克模式，这种模式以路易斯·CK (Louis CK) 的《Louie》为首，并由唐纳德·格洛弗 (Donald Glover) 的《亚特兰大》推向顶峰：形式和色调上善变的、导演主导的、容易绕道的、印象派的半小时喜剧。 （称之为“外汇情绪片”。）其结果可能更容易令人钦佩，而不是迷失其中。强调集体。 （对话中充满了土著俚语和它自己的万能咒语“shitass”，同样独特。）到了第三季，奥肯已经涵盖了精神、民俗和历史，有效地重新定义了什么社区还可以。除了单亲妈妈、阿姨和祖母之外，还有一位 19 世纪的武士精神（达拉斯·金牙饰），他促使贝尔进行自我反省；埃洛拉（Elora）去世的母亲，永远二十岁的库奇（JaNae Collins）；还有充满复仇欲望的鹿女士（卡尼赫蒂奥·霍恩饰），她是一位永恒的流浪者，她的迪斯科时代牛仔连身裤下藏着蹄子。

;

;Harjo 的项目——一个满嘴脏话、受艺术风格启发的向原住民耐力的致敬社区，以及确保他们坚持下去的真诚呼吁——电视上没有类似的内容。他的使命体现在该剧对长老的特别关注，其中许多人由著名的土著角色演员扮演。 《保留地狗》表达了对这些人物为下一代提供的文化财富的崇敬，但最重要的是，也坚持他们的错误和人性。这个枯萎圈子里的每个成员都有自己的怪癖：艺术家巴基（韦斯·斯塔迪饰）试图用他神秘的雕像来抵御疾病；药师菲克斯科（理查德·雷·惠特曼饰）在印度诊所外兜售“真正的药物”；部落警察大个子（扎恩·麦克拉农饰）宁愿追捕大脚怪，也不愿追捕少年犯。尽管他们渴望传递传统知识，但他们不太愿意谈论塑造他们的个人创伤。新一季最关键的一集《烟枪之家》展现了福特政府时期的长辈们作为高中生的故事。就像现代的 Rez Dogs 一样，他们是一群粗鲁、关系紧密的人，处于政治意识的风口浪尖，对吸毒比上课更感兴趣。在迷幻药之旅结束后，十几岁的巴基嘀咕着这很可能是该系列的主题：“从不寻找自己是谁，这真是太美好了。你所需要的一切都在你镜子里的数千年的确定性中。”然后马克西姆斯——他们小组中的丹尼尔，一个孤儿，那天晚上第一次被外星亲属或精神分裂症幻觉拜访——从他朋友的掌控中溜走，使宇宙凝聚力的断言变得复杂化。几十年后，当贝尔偶然遇到头发花白的马克西姆斯（格雷厄姆·格林饰）时，这位老人被从奥肯流放成为了一个警示故事。

;

;哈乔对代际纽带的强烈甚至焦虑的关注逐渐暴露了该系列的一些内容'的缺点。写作变得更加说教，并且，通过继续缩小范围，“保留狗”放弃了一些更发自内心的乐趣：即与帮派一起闲逛的时间。他们在镇上低调的短途旅行——去他们的鲶鱼店、健康中心或各种长者的家——被有时蜿蜒的一对一场景所取代，这些场景给几集带来了室内剧的霉味。

;
;
;

;大结局让小熊、埃洛拉、奶酪和威利杰克进入成年，对他们的文化遗产有了新的认识，给这个许多人认为过早结束的系列带来了一种结束感。但是，虽然奥肯生活的特质被以充满爱意的细节呈现，但青少年本身仍然是原型，而不是完全有说服力的原型——部分原因是他们与同龄人的其他人有多么疏远。 （核心群体只有在被其他孩子伏击后才与他们互动。）雷兹狗似乎很少关注生日、舞会或毕业等传统的里程碑——他们最有意义的社交聚会是长辈的葬礼。尽管我们知道贝尔和埃洛拉是青少年妈妈的孩子，但剧组将性视为一个陌生的概念；甚至暗恋也很少见。这些“全美国”的青春期门柱的缺失可能令人耳目一新，它们不像好莱坞让我们相信的那么普遍。然而，这种描述也有一些令人难以置信的孩子气——也许是防御性的健康。过了这么久，这帮人之间的联系仍然很深。除了回忆丹尼尔之外，我不能说我知道他们在构成生活的安静时刻会谈论什么。

;

;在节目接近尾声时，我们看到“保留狗”可以完成什么当它使青少年脱离自己的故事时。在名为“Wahoo！”的精彩剧集中，小熊的妈妈丽塔（莎拉·波德姆斯基饰）接待了她已故朋友曲奇的来访，而这位即将成为空巢老人的小熊正在考虑一旦她不在家，可能会出现的可能性。不再需要把儿子放在第一位。曲奇请丽塔去看看埃洛拉的情况，弧线以一个感人的仪式结束，让灵魂知道她不再需要如此密切地关注她的女儿；阿姨们发誓要代替她这样做，让库奇安息。

;

;但最后一季的故事情节和人物也因哈乔对大局的专注而受到影响。例如，故意混淆了关系疏远的表兄弟马克西姆斯和菲克斯科之间的冲突，使他们期待已久的重聚不像预期的那样令人心酸。鹿女士在一所印度寄宿学校度过的童年的故事，以及埃洛拉与她的白人父亲（伊桑·霍克饰）的邂逅，她以为父亲多年前就已经去世了，这一切都显得很模糊。 “我不想让你远离这一切。 。 。 。来自你的家人，来自你的人民，”他告诉她，并解释了为什么他在她年轻时离开了。他非常了解她的世界——他引用了她的祖母、她的篮球教练，甚至奥肯的绰号“shitass”。但他痛苦地意识到，他对;她;知之甚少。即使在埃洛拉的公司待了三年，一些观众可能也会有同样的感觉。 ♦

;法国导演贾斯汀的新片《跌倒的解剖》中提出的第一个问题Triet，很简单：“你想知道什么？”这句话可以作为整部电影的座右铭，是作家桑德拉·沃伊特（桑德拉·惠勒饰）在阿尔卑斯山的一间小屋里说的。她正在接受研究生 Zoé（卡米尔·卢瑟福饰）的采访，尽管他们的谈话很快就被上面的喧闹声淹没了——特别是 50 Cent 的器乐版“PIMP”，由桑德拉的丈夫以雷鸣般的轰鸣声演奏。塞缪尔·泰斯（Samuel Theis），同时也是一名作家。他要么是故意破坏采访，要么是想引发一场雪崩。

;

;我们暂时看不到塞缪尔本人的任何迹象，这很重要。预示着故事将如何展开。 《跌倒解剖》中的很多内容都是无意中听到的、听到但没有看到、看到但被误解、误记、凭猜测而产生，或者不明智地相信。当我们看到塞缪尔时，他已经死了——躺在小屋旁边的雪地里，颅骨上有一道深深的伤口，还有一道血迹。那么，他是从阳台上摔下来还是被推了？他的头是撞到了下面棚屋的边缘，还是已经受到打击了？他是死于自己之手，还是死于桑德拉之手？ 50 Cent有嫌疑吗？谜题激增。警告：不要指望所有问题都能得到解决。

;

;桑德拉和塞缪尔有一个儿子丹尼尔，十一岁，由米洛·马查多·格兰纳饰演，他完美地融合了脆弱和决心。丹尼尔的边境牧羊犬史努普由梅西扮演，表演同样引人注目，梅西的技巧会让他的同名者羡慕不已。史努比不仅是丹尼尔的同伴，也是他的助手，因为丹尼尔四岁时在一次事故中受伤，留下了严重的视力障碍。 （通常情况下，该事件的细节及其漫长的后果需要一段时间才能浮现。特里特是缓慢泄密的专家。）是他与史努比散步回来，发现了他父亲的尸体，并向桑德拉哭诉。音乐仍在震耳欲聋，但她听到了哭声。为什么会这样？

;

;我们还没有到达片头，Triet 已经把我们带到了她想要的地方。这不是一部侦探电影；这是一部侦探电影。有警察，但他们在情节的边缘徘徊，也没有波洛从附近的山谷里绕过去，掸掉胡子上的积雪，然后处理案件。相反，;我们;成为侦探——阅读每一个符文，探究漏洞，并测试证据，就像我们在冰上行走一样。 “我必须理解，”丹尼尔说，他的强迫症具有感染力。需要澄清的不仅是犯罪行为（如果确实是犯罪的话），还有他父母的婚姻状况，一段时间以来，他们的婚姻已经破裂和融化。据桑德拉说，这是基于“智力刺激”。爱情就到此为止了。

;

;这个故事几乎没有一个方面摸起来不滑溜溜的。桑德拉是德国人，但来到塞缪尔长大的法国生活，显然对她所说的他的地盘感到不安。她主要用英语说话——作为一种妥协，或者为了寻求共同点——他们抚养丹尼尔的语言，她是一个对母语毫无用处的母亲。她承认自己在结婚期间曾与其他人发生过关系，而现在，雪上加霜的是，她还得到了一位曾经与她有过关系的臭名昭著的律师文森特·伦齐（斯万·阿劳德饰）的服务。他也很受欢迎，因为桑德拉被指控谋杀塞缪尔。 “我没有杀他！”她对文森特大声喊道，紧急回答了一个他甚至没有问过的问题——这也许是影片中最令人震惊的闯入。然而，无论文森特私下相信什么，他的辩护计划都是声称塞缪尔自杀。就这样进入审判阶段。

;
;
;

;在今年戛纳电影节上获得金棕榈奖的《坠落解剖》被广泛称为法庭剧。是的，后半部分的大部分内容都是在格勒诺布尔的法庭上进行的，但你很少会有这样的印象：特里特——她和搭档阿瑟·哈拉里一起写了剧本——陷入了法律机制之中。事实上，电视上的法律节目或奥托·普雷明格组织清晰的《谋杀案剖析》（1959）的粉丝将会对特里特电影中自由形式的诉讼过程感到惊讶。律师、证人和一两个“飞溅分析师”似乎随意或随机地互相打断，通常是坐着的。检察官（安托万·雷纳茨饰演），剃着光头，傻笑着，四处走动，大声咆哮，而我，就是其中之一，会毫不犹豫地将他从高高的窗户扔出去。这个场景最像一家小酒馆，里面挤满了争吵的法律系学生，你可能会期待法庭书记员端着几碗洋葱汤到来。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;最有说服力的片段集中在丹尼尔身上，因为他站在那里接受辩方和控方的质询，根据他的证词。镜头左右旋转，强化了他被围攻的感觉，这个动作引发了两种想法。第一，无论在哪个司法管辖区，都可以以这种敌对的方式盘问儿童吗？如果是这样，为什么证据应该被裁定为可采？第二，特里特对我们的影响是否如此恶作剧，以至于我们不再关心什么是合理的，而只渴望电影核心的意志斗争？我认为，这与其说是一场法庭戏剧，不如说是一场不和谐、高度紧张的角色冲突，并附加了法律的花哨内容。请注意我们最终是如何得知判决结果的：不是在法庭上，而是在正式公告中，而是通过外面的一名电视记者，听到她身后传来兴奋的喧闹声。真相并不是晶莹剔透、清晰可见的。它散落成碎片，你必须尽你所能把它们捡起来。

;

;一个实用的提示：“跌倒的解剖”是一部令人敬畏的东西，你应该安排在电影院与你的朋友一起观看它。最挑剔的朋友，最好是在六点钟，这样你就可以在晚餐时讨论事情——我建议火锅，因为它可以方便地闻到阿尔卑斯山的混乱冒泡的味道。尽管格勒诺布尔已经做出了判决，但你很可能仍然不确定桑德拉是否有罪，而更关键的是：即使是扮演她的人也不确定。惠勒透露，在拍摄电影期间，她反复询问特里特桑德拉是否做了这件事。 Triet 拒绝尖叫。

;

;奇迹在于，这种不确定性使得 Hüller 的表演更加尖锐而不是模糊。据报道，桑德拉（她的丈夫是一个虚弱的灵魂，也是一个不太成功的作家）形容她“相当阉割”，就好像她已经武装自己以应对所有的意外事件和敌人。由于她心慌意乱、面露冷色，不需要盘问就能让她勃然大怒，而我们的反应是惊叹于她的不安之深，也许还有她的狡诈。当她在寒冷的夜晚站在外面，一边喝酒一边与律师调情时，她是在抓住难得的放松机会，还是在巧妙地让他进一步走向她的事业？我们有多喜欢或不喜欢桑德拉并不重要。令人不安的是，我们无法决定，从一个场景到下一个场景，我们有多么坚定地想要支持她。

;

;Hüller 曾出演过 Triet 早期且不太连贯的电影《Sibyl》。 （2019），奇怪的是，其中有一个名叫马列斯基的家伙，就像塞缪尔一样，和一个名叫丹尼尔的脆弱男孩。此外，在这两部电影中，对话都是被秘密记录的。在《西比尔》中，一位心理医生用录音带记录了病人的倾诉。现在，在《跌倒剖析》中，我们了解到塞缪尔在去世前不久录制了他与桑德拉的激烈争吵。结果在法庭上大声播放，特里特将其转化为闪回，这意味着我们既看到也听到了婚姻风暴——这是法官和陪审员被剥夺的特权。 （讽刺的是，音频版本的空洞影响更大。）这是一个流畅的创意花招，还是电影在欺骗我们？特里特是否会效仿她自己的女主人公的狡猾领导？

;

;事实上，围绕这部电影的这种怀疑和保留并不是反对它的标志。相反，他们尊重其挑衅的能力。这就是为什么但以理具有如此道德分量的原因。当他承认“我搞混了”时，他比任何成年人都更诚实地认识到混乱的本质。看着他那双困惑的眼睛，既能看见又看不见，我们不禁想知道：何时、在什么样的情感压力下，记忆会从对某事的可靠描述转变为我们讲述的故事我们自己是否知道我们希望发生的事情？丹尼尔成为这种失误的牺牲品也就不足为奇了。毕竟，他是两位作家的儿子，当检察官读出桑德拉一本书中的威胁性段落，试图将她定罪时，他会倾听。 （不错的尝试，;Maître;。按照这条路线，你的监狱里就会挤满小说家。）不过，忘记那些聪明的技巧吧。如果你真的想知道小屋里那决定命运的一天发生了什么，只有一个行动方案。问问史努比。 ♦

;将 Justine's on Hudson 想象成西村小酒馆，艾米丽（巴黎）和嘉莉（来自巴黎）疫情后的城市）可能会在周六晚上相约喝一瓶苏玳葡萄酒。外面铺着白色桌布四顶，方便观察绿树成荫的街道上昂贵的高跟鞋的嘎嘎声。里面有灰色的皮革长椅、闪闪发光的黄铜，还有一盏由倒置的郁金香花瓣制成的华丽枝形吊灯，无论是作为包还是帽子，戴在嘉莉或艾米丽身上都不会显得格格不入。

;

;在某种程度上，贾斯汀酒庄（Justine's）以其业主、上东区著名葡萄酒进口商尼尔·罗森塔尔（Neal Rosenthal）的女儿命名，让人回想起一个不同的时代，当时的经济更加繁荣，公开的奢侈也不再那么粗俗。但是，话又说回来，在 2023 年，即使是一家平均每瓶售价在 150 美元左右的高档小酒馆，也给人一种非常 2023 年的感觉。最近的一个晚上，一位和蔼可亲但略显忙碌的服务员道歉说，工作人员不再配备侍酒师，并且最便宜的一杯葡萄酒（十五美元的桃红葡萄酒）刚刚用完。

;
;
;

;菲律宾-法国菜单上的菜品按季节轮换。那天晚上的七道开胃菜中，最不迷人的一道却是最吸引人的。黄瓜生牛肉片，与焦糖南瓜籽和罗勒混合，是对夏天的完美校准，秋天的变化，我的味觉不知道它需要夏天的告别。无处不在的传家宝西红柿与香草盐李子片和人参醋一起被赋予了新的、明亮的生命。 “当我小的时候，我的母亲对新泽西州中国杂货店里的所有人参都着迷，”餐厅 34 岁的菲律宾裔美国厨师珍妮·乔丹 (Jeanne Jordan) 笑着告诉我。 “所以我猜人参醋淋到了我身上。”

;;;;

;偶尔，值得称赞的精神游戏会离开乔丹。虾吐司第一口就很美味，但很快就因为黄油、格鲁耶尔干酪和培根的丰富而变得无边无际。同样，美味的猪排——可能是菜单上最传统的菲律宾菜——涂上厚厚的奶油比利比酱，撒上大量的贻贝，淋上鳟鱼籽，在离开厨房之前，它可能已经去除了至少一件珠宝。

;

;Jordan 的最佳创作是辣蟹意大利面，其灵感来自于她从小到大吃的蟹炒饭。 “这是我们不会从菜单上删除的一项，”她自豪地说。清淡、有弹性的面条，配上丝滑的蟹肉，几乎让人难以下咽，酱汁是由红辣椒皮斯托、大蒜泥、陈年帕尔马干酪和碎胡椒片混合而成的难以捉摸的混合物，带来诱人的、闪烁的热量。 “如果你喜欢这个，你应该在我们用蟹子的时候尝试一下。这非常非常好，”乔丹说道。 “但它也非常非常昂贵。” （;菜肴 $23-$46。;） ♦

;最近，我们中的一些右翼人士建议唐纳德·特朗普的几位政治对手和刑事检察官应该被弹劾。我们为了民主的利益而援引这一宪法工具，这样做是一个令人自豪但庄严的决定。很多人都认为这些举动是政治戏剧，共和党正在不顾一切地提出潜在的弹劾。对于那些批评者，我们说：这是弹劾言论。

;

;当我们提出对特朗普的主要政治对手乔·拜登进行弹劾调查时，人们说我们只是想安抚特朗普，肆意援引“弹劾”一词。 ”。好吧，先生，这种无礼行为是一张通往弹劾维尔的单程票，人口：你。

;

;请让我们弹劾你。做吧。说真的——我们;想要;。

;

;我们还呼吁弹劾一位公开反对不公正划分选区的州最高法院法官，并且我们认为指控特朗普选举不公的地方检察官欺诈行为首先应该被免职。您认为试图阻止我们不喜欢的刑事审判是对弹劾的不负责任的使用吗？因为如果你这样做了，我们就会准备一份写有你名字的弹劾三明治。

;

;但是要留点空间吃甜点。我们将为我们举世闻名的弹劾鞋匠服务。

;

;让我问你这个问题：如果共和党政客像你所说的那样热衷于弹劾，那么为什么我们自己的州长布莱恩·坎普 (Brian Kemp) 却这么做呢？ ，捍卫地方检察官的记录并拒绝更多弹劾的呼吁？打败了我们。但有一件事是肯定的：布莱恩·坎普现在;;正在被弹劾。

;

;我发誓。你们正在寻求弹劾。

;

;您可能想知道这是否合法。我们将把这个问题留给法律专家。但不是我们的。昨晚我们弹劾了所有律师。我们能说什么？在所有其他弹劾谈话之后，我们感觉“处于状态”，所以我们想，为什么不孤注一掷呢？我们的亲人表示，也许我们已经“受够了”一次国会会议的弹劾，但既然他们也遭到了弹劾，我们怎么能相信他们呢？

;
;
;

;我们可能永远不知道开国元勋们是否在宪法中加入弹劾条款，只是为了让我们能够安抚我们基地中那些有阴谋论的边缘人。但是，如果我们能回到过去询问他们，我们可能会弹劾那些反对第二修正案的开国元勋。然后我们会回到更远的过去，弹劾所有应该被弹劾但在弹劾成为现实之前就已经去世的人。就像莎士比亚（让男孩打扮成女孩）、恐龙（反驳神创论）和德古拉一样。

;

;所以，下次当你怀疑我们的爱国主义或对法律的尊重时，不要告诉自己，或者你会发现自己正处于弹劾的最后阶段。抱歉，您不喜欢我们的方法，但有时像弹劾这样的激烈行为是揭露真相的唯一方法。除非我们不同意结果，否则那些弹劾者将被弹劾。 ♦

;;;< em>;您正在阅读《Goings On》时事通讯，这是我们本周观看、收听和做的事情的指南。;注册以在您的收件箱中接收它。;; ;;

;;最近一个气候温和的星期二;;晚上;在纽约市，;;Mitski;; 在市政厅登台表演了一套简约的原声布景。这位三十三岁的歌手兼作曲家过去曾与一支完整的摇滚乐队一起巡演。她向往的孤独和流离失所的歌曲在模糊的音墙的衬托下呈现出史诗般的比例。但在她目前的一系列演出中，为了支持她的第七张录音室专辑《The Land Is Inhospitable and So Are We》，米茨基采取了极简主义风格，在一张三十二分钟的唱片中直接演唱，只有一名吉他手和一名站立贝斯手伴奏。 。结果是原始的、暴露的，但并不感觉脆弱；米茨基的声音在刺耳的女低音和鸟儿般甜美的女高音之间无缝切换，听起来比多年来更强劲。米茨基在欧洲各地进行的精简演出持续到十月，她将自己置于标志性民间艺术家的行列中，他们只需要合唱和一些和弦就可以让听众感动落泪。她的声调带有琼·贝兹 (Joan Baez) 的影子，她的抒情智慧与乔尼·米切尔 (Joni Mitchell) 相呼应（“嘿，怎么了？看起来像你的贴纸/粘在地板上的某个地方，”米茨基在异想天开的“Bug Like an Angel”中唱道） ”）。在市政厅的加演中，米茨基翻唱了皮特·西格的《土狼，我的小兄弟》，表达了她对他在哈德逊河谷的环保活动的钦佩。当她唱出对人为气候悲剧的哀歌时，她的高音域因愤怒而颤动。这是一个激动人心的时刻，让我很兴奋地想看看她接下来会用她的声音做什么。

;
;;
;

;今年秋天标志着新音乐和巡演的丰收时期由处于才华巅峰的女性所创造。 ;;Boygenius;，;由 Lucy Dacus、Phoebe Bridgers 和 Julien Baker 组成的摇滚超级乐队在万圣节期间在好莱坞露天剧场演出，他们于 10 月 13 日发行了一张新的四首歌 EP“therest”，这是乐队成功首演的快速后续行动录音室专辑“唱片”。不拘一格的英国歌手科琳·贝利·雷 (Corinne Bailey Rae) 在九月份推出了她七年来的第一张专辑《Black Rainbows》，并在整个秋季进行巡回演出以宣传它。 ;艾莉森·拉塞尔 (Allison Russell)，一位加拿大艺术大师，其生动的歌曲创作借鉴了迪斯科、另类乡村和黑人根源音乐，最近推出了一张精彩的大二唱片《The Returner》，并在威廉斯堡音乐厅演奏11 月 30 日。;;玛格丽特·格拉斯皮;，<一位独立摇滚歌手传递了 Alanis Morissette、Shirley Manson 和 Shawn Colvin 的 90 年代活力，于 10 月 20 日在 Bowery Ballroom 演唱了她的新专辑《Echo the Diamond》中的歌曲。 10 月 12 日至 13 日，您可以欣赏讽刺的澳大利亚歌手 ;;考特尼·巴尼特;;在国家锯末； 10 月 20 日至 21 日，性感英国艺术家 ;;Jessie Ware;; 在 5 号航站楼演出两晚；同样在 10 月 21 日，势不可挡的 Héloïse Letissier 将扮演法国变形流行歌手 ;;克里斯汀和皇后;，;降临汉默斯坦舞厅。现在是制作秋季混音带的激动人心的时刻，其中有大量新鲜歌曲为您走过落叶的脚步配乐。

;
;;

;聚光灯

;;
;;
;
;艺术
;

;认识艺术家的人;朱迪·芝加哥;仅对她的女权主义装置作品“晚宴”（1974-79）感到惊讶，她的调查展览“她的故事”于 10 月 12 日在新博物馆开幕，其折衷主义风格可能会让您感到惊讶。 1968 年，当警察忙着向和平抗议者发射催泪瓦斯时，她让加利福尼亚州帕萨迪纳的一条街道笼罩在温和的白色烟雾中。随后出现了类似的表演作品，并且有一个强有力的论据认为烟雾是她完成最好作品的媒介。 1969 年，她曾短暂地将圣巴巴拉艺术博物馆的外墙笼罩在黄橙色的薄雾中（如图）。 “我想看看是否能让它看起来像是被烧毁了，”她解释道。 “博物馆对女性艺术家的作品非常不友好。”——;;杰克逊·阿恩;（新博物馆；至一月. 14.);

;
;
;;
;<内联-embed name="align-center" attrs="[object Object]" childTypes="" contentType="callout:align-center">;

;关于城镇

;;
;另类摇滚
;

;2013 年，当新加坡歌手兼制作人 Nat Ćmiel 在 SoundCloud 上首次推出他们的音乐项目 ;yeule; 时，艺术家的目录主要由梦幻般的、虚幻的流行音乐组成。 Ćmiel 将他们 2019 年的首张专辑《Serotonin II》的声音称为网络哥特和后流行音乐，暗示了音乐的机械化本质及其微妙的、合成的忧郁。 yeule 化身让 Ćmiel 能够正视性别焦虑，而音乐（由轻柔、纤细的歌声萦绕的故障电子乐）则专注于人工智能。从2022年起，yeule凭借全合成专辑《Glitch Princess》完成了一场自动化的音乐进化。但就在这位艺术家似乎完全变成了机器人时，一张新专辑“softscars”采取了明显的人性化方式。它既脏乱又激烈，拥抱另类摇滚，寻找一种有感觉的形式。-;;Sheldon Pearce; （韦伯斯特大厅；10 月 15 日。）;

;
;
;剧院
;

;在一间黑暗的房间里，一位不愿透露姓名的技术官僚（史蒂夫·梅勒饰）坐在麦克风前，将自己的人生故事诉诸于一种被称为“时间封装器”的东西：其他人怎么敢因为他的生态灭绝发明而获得赞誉？为什么他的同事——尤其是那些没有被他亲自致残的同事——不支持他？声音沙哑的梅勒，超级干燥，超级滑稽，是一个奥运会级别的愤怒的毛茸茸的人，而杰瑞·李布里奇的《Mahinerator》，滑稽可怕的科幻独白，就像一件毛衣一样适合他。李布里希用令人混乱的暗语创作，一半是宗教狂想曲（他引用了“不公正的萨拉米香肠”）和新词（例如“broomlicloset”），让人想起“发条橙”。由利布利希和梅根·芬恩共同执导的最终作品令人反感但又令人兴奋——它仅用语言来融化你的大脑。-;;Helen Shaw;（《坦克》；截至 10 月 22 日。）;

;
;
;歌剧
;
;;
;

;作曲家杰克·赫吉 (Jake Heggie) 扣人心弦的;《行尸走肉》;改编自海伦·普雷让修女 (Helen Prejean) 的回忆录，讲述了在死牢里照顾杀人犯的故事，将道德清算推迟到了歌剧的最后二十分钟。舞台上，摄制组跟踪海伦（犀利的乔伊斯·迪多纳托饰）和被定罪的杀人犯约瑟夫·德罗彻（粗犷的瑞安·麦金尼饰），用极端特写镜头拍摄了两个在自怜中难以看清自己的角色（更不用说地狱之火了）后台冒出滚滚浓烟）。在伊沃·范霍夫的新作品中，迪多纳托脉动的声音穿透了乐谱的丰富肤浅（由雅尼克·内泽特-塞甘生动地指挥），她和麦金尼，他的低音男中音在黑暗中，最终在漫长而严峻的阴影中找到了彼此。死刑。—;;Oussama Zahr;（大都会歌剧院；选择日期为 10 月 12 日至 21 日。） ;

;
;
;舞蹈
;

;神话、魔法、自然和性别的奥秘——这些都是编舞家克里斯托弗·威廉姆斯 (Christopher Williams) 着迷的主题。他的最新项目是对二十世纪初佳吉列夫俄罗斯芭蕾舞团创作的两部作品的重新思考：瓦斯拉夫·尼金斯基的“Jeux”（或“游戏”）和莱昂尼德·马辛的“Contes Russes”。在《Jeux》中，威廉姆斯提供了尼金斯基网球比喻的替代场景，讲述了一个不断变化的性吸引力的故事。在《一个孩子的故事》中，编舞者探索了巴巴亚嘎的神话，这是一个巫婆般的角色，经常出现在威廉姆斯的乌克兰曾祖母小时候给他讲的斯拉夫民间故事中。-;;Marina Harss;（巴里什尼科夫艺术中心；10 月 12 日至 15 日。）;

;
;
;电影
;;

;艾拉·萨克斯 (Ira Sachs) 的巴黎情景剧“;Passages;” 现已在 MUBI 上播放。为此，他为该网站编写了一系列节目，其中包括另一部伟大的浪漫剧《无辜者》，这是意大利导演卢奇诺·维斯康蒂 (Luchino Visconti) 1976 年的最后一部电影，讲述了罗马人的华丽而激动人心的故事。十九世纪末的贵族阶层。故事以一位潇洒的浪荡子（吉安卡洛·贾尼尼饰）为中心，他娶了一个情人（詹妮弗·奥尼尔饰），并让他被忽视的妻子（劳拉·安东内利饰）自由地追求自己的浪漫追求，但在他嫉妒地与她和解后，她发现她怀孕了却被另一个人所左右，导致了悲惨的结果。华丽的场景和优雅的人物举止掩盖了上流社会普遍存在的残酷——最重要的是，男人的骄傲和权力的残酷。——;;理查德·布罗迪;（在 MUBI 上直播。）;

;

;网站 Stack Overflow 于 2008 年创建，是程序员互相回答问题的地方。当时，网络上高质量的技术信息很少。如果你在编码时遇到困难并且需要帮助，那么你最好的选择是旧的、分散的论坛帖子，这些帖子通常不会有任何结果。杰夫·阿特伍德 (Jeff Atwood) 和乔尔·斯波尔斯基 (Joel Spolsky) 是两位著名的软件开发人员，他们试图通过将编程问题转变为问题来解决这个问题。 A. 变成一种多人游戏。 On Stack Overflow—the name refers to a common way that programs crash—people could earn points for posting popular questions and leaving helpful answers. Points earned badges and special privileges; users would be motivated by a mix of altruism and glory.

;

;Within three years of its founding, Stack Overflow had become indispensable to working programmers, who consulted it daily. Pages from Stack Overflow dominated programming search results; the site had more than sixteen million unique visitors a month out of an estimated nine million programmers worldwide. Almost ninety per cent of them arrived through Google. The same story was playing out across the Web: this was the era of “Web 2.0,” and sites that could extract knowledge from people's heads and organize it for others were thriving. Yelp, Reddit, Flickr, Goodreads, Tumblr, and Stack Overflow all launched within a few years of one another, during a period when Google was experiencing its own extraordinary growth. Web 2.0 and Google fuelled each other: by indexing these crowdsourced knowledge projects, Google could get its arms around vast, dense repositories of high-quality information for free, and those same sites could acquire users and contributors through Google. The search company's rapacious pursuit of other people's data was excused by the fact that it drove users toward the content it harvested. In those days, Google even measured its success partly by how quickly users left its search pages: a short stay meant that a user had found what they were looking for.

;

;All this started to change almost as soon as it had begun. Around that time, Google launched the OneBox, a feature that provided searchers with instant answers above search results. (Search for movie times, and you'd get them in the OneBox, above a list of links to movie theatres.) The feature siphoned traffic from the very sites that made it possible. Yelp was an instructive case: Google wanted to compete in the “local” market but didn't have its own repository of restaurant and small-business reviews. Luther Lowe, Yelp's former head of public policy, told me recently that Google tried everything it could to claw its way in, from licensing Yelp's data (Yelp declined) to encouraging its own users to write reviews (no one wanted to contribute at the time) or even buying Yelp outright (it declined again). “Once those strategies failed—license, compete on the merits, purchase the content—what did they have left?” Lowe said. “They had to steal it.” In 2010 and 2011, Lowe says, Yelp caught Google scraping their content with no attribution. The data gave Google just enough momentum to bootstrap its own reviews product. When Yelp publicly accused Google of stealing its data, the company stopped, but the damage had already been done. (A similar thing happened at a company I once worked for, called Genius. We sued Google for copying lyrics from our database into the OneBox; I helped prove that it was happening by embedding a hidden message into the lyrics, using a pattern of apostrophes that, in Morse code, spelled “;RED HANDED;.” Google won in appellate court, in the Second Circuit. Genius petitioned the Supreme Court to hear the case, but the court declined.)

;

;In 2012, Google doubled down on the OneBox with a redesign that deëmphasized the classic blue links to external Web sites in favor of Google's own properties, like Shopping and Maps, and immediate answers culled from sites like Wikipedia. This made Google even more convenient and powerful, but also had the effect of starving the Web of users: instead of a search leading you to a Wikipedia page, say, where you might join the small percentage of visitors who end up contributing, you'd get your answer straight from Google. According to Lowe, on pages of search results featuring the new design, as many as eighty per cent of searchers would leave without ever clicking on a link. Many Web 2.0 darlings, dense with user-generated content, saw visitor numbers decline. It was around this time that, in some sense, the quality of the Web as a whole began to decline, with the notable exception of the few crowdsourced knowledge projects that managed to survive. There's a reason that appending “reddit” or “wiki” to search terms has become an indispensable productivity hack: in a hollowed-out Web overrun with spammers and content farms, these have become some of the last places where real, knowledgeable humans hang out.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Today, large language models, like OpenAI's ChatGPT and Google's Bard, are completing a process begun by the OneBox: their goal is to ingest the Web so comprehensively that it might as well not exist. The question is whether this approach is sustainable. LLMs depend for their intelligence on vast repositories of human writing—the artifacts of ;our; intelligence. They especially depend on information-dense sources. In creating ChatGPT, Wikipedia was OpenAI's most important data set, followed by Reddit; about twenty-two per cent of GPT-3's training data comprised Web pages linked to and upvoted by Reddit users. ChatGPT is such a good programmer that the savvy developers I know aren't using Stack Overflow anymore—and yet it's partly by studying Stack Overflow that ChatGPT became such a good programmer. Recently, a group of researchers estimated that the number of new posts on Stack Overflow has decreased by sixteen per cent since the launch of ChatGPT.

;

;I'm not a Stack Overflow power user, but I am a coder, and I've relied on the site for more than a decade. I've submitted projects to GitHub (a site for open-source code), posted on Reddit, and edited Wikipedia pages. Meanwhile, I've published blog posts and code to my Web site for years. Like everyone else, I didn't suspect that I was producing GPT fodder; if I'd known, I might have asked for something in return, or even withheld my contributions. In April, the CEO of Reddit announced that, from then on, any company that required large-scale data from its site would have to pay for the privilege. (Because the move threatened other, non-AI-related apps, Reddit users responded by “blacking out” huge swaths of the site, emphasizing that the company's fortunes depended on uncompensated community contributions.) Stack Overflow has made a similar announcement.

;
;
;

;Maybe the crowdsourcing sites will manage to wall off their content. But it may not matter. High-quality data is not necessarily a renewable resource, especially if you treat it like a vast virgin oil field, yours for the taking. The sites that have fuelled chatbots function like knowledge economies, using various kinds of currency—points, bounties, badges, bonuses—to broker information to where it is most needed, and chatbots are already thinning out the demand side of these marketplaces, starving the human engines that created the knowledge in the first place. This is a problem for us, of course: we all benefit from a human-powered Web. But it's also a problem for AI It's possible that AIs can only hoover up the whole Web once. If they are to continue getting smarter, they will need new reservoirs of knowledge. Where will it come from?

;

;AI companies have already turned their attention to one possible source: chat. Anyone who uses a chatbot like Bard or ChatGPT is participating in a massive training exercise. In fact, one reason that these bots are provided for free may be that a user's data is more valuable than her money: everything you type into a chatbot's text box is grist for its model. Moreover, we aren't just typing but pasting—e-mails, documents, code, manuals, contracts, and so on. We're often asking the bots to summarize this material and then asking pointed questions about it, conducting a kind of close-reading seminar. Currently, there's a limit to how much you can paste into a bot's input box, but the amount of new data we can feed them at a gulp will only grow.

;

;It won't be long before many of us also start bulk-importing our most private documents into these models. A chatbot hasn't yet asked me to grant it access to my e-mail archives—or to my texts, calendar, notes, and files. But, in exchange for a capable AI personal assistant, I could be tempted to compromise my privacy. A personal-assistant bot might nudge me to install a browser extension that tracks where I go on the Web so that it can learn from my detailed searching and browsing patterns. And ChatGPT and its ilk will soon become “multimodal,” able to fluidly blend and produce text, images, videos, and sound. Most language is actually spoken rather than written, and so bots will offer to help us by transcribing our meetings and phone calls, or even our everyday interactions.

;

;Before models like GPT-3.5 and GPT-4 made their way into the user-facing ChatGPT product, they were tuned with what OpenAI calls “reinforcement learning from human feedback,” or RLHF Essentially, OpenAI paid human testers to have conversations with the raw model and rate the quality of its replies; the model learned from these ratings, aligning its responses ever more finely with our intentions. It's because of RLHF that ChatGPT is so eerily good at understanding exactly what you're asking and what a good answer should look like. This process was likely expensive. But now RLHF can be had for free, and at a much bigger scale, through conversations with real-world users. This is true even if you don't click one of the thumbs-up, thumbs-down, or “This was helpful”-style buttons at the bottom of a chat transcript. GPT-4 is so good at interpreting writing that it can examine a chat transcript and decide for itself whether it did a good job serving you. One model's conversations can even bootstrap another's: it's been claimed that rivals to ChatGPT, such as Google Bard, finished their training by consuming ChatGPT transcripts that had been posted online. (Google has denied this.)

;
;
;

;The use of chatbots to evaluate and train other chatbots points the way toward the eventual goal of removing humans from the loop entirely. Perhaps the most fundamental limitation of today's large language models is that they depend on knowledge that's been generated by people. A sea change will come when the bots can generate knowledge for themselves. One possible path involves what's known as synthetic data. For a long time now, AI researchers have padded their data sets as a matter of course: a neural network trained on images, for instance, might undergo a preprocessing step in which each image is rotated ninety degrees, or shrunk, or mirrored, creating for each picture eight or sixteen variants. But the doctoring can be much more involved than that. In autonomous-vehicle research, capturing real-world driving data is incredibly expensive, because you have to outfit an actual car with sensors and drive it around; it's much cheaper to build a simulated car and run it through a virtual environment with simulated roads and weather conditions. It's now typical to train state-of-the-art self-driving AIs by driving them for millions of miles on the road and billions in simulation.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;;Sam Altman;, the CEO of OpenAI, has said that synthetic data might also soon overtake the real thing in training runs for LLMs The idea would be to have a GPT-esque model generate documents, conversations, and evaluations of how those conversations went, and then for another model—perhaps just a copy of the first—to ingest them. The hope is to enter a training regime similar to that of ;AIs designed for games; like chess and Go, which learn largely through “self-play.” In each step of training, the AI learns something about the game by playing an opponent that's exactly its equal; from that experience, it improves just a little bit, and then the slightly better version of the bot squares off against its slightly-better self and improves again. Up and up it goes. By playing a perfectly matched opponent—itself—an AI can even get into interesting positions deep within games, exploring the game world at exactly the frontier of its existing knowledge in a way that humans never do. This strategy is uncannily effective: the game-playing AI AlphaZero started its training run knowing nothing but the rules of chess and, after four hours, had surpassed every player, human or machine, there had ever been.

;

;Altman is bullish on synthetic data, but there are reasons to be skeptical—including the obvious one that, no matter how smart you are, you can't learn new facts about the world by reviewing what you already know. In a recent study, researchers trained an AI model with synthetic images that it had generated; they then used the resulting model to generate even more training data. With each generation, the quality of the model actually degraded. It only improved when fresh, real images were introduced again. It stands to reason that some tasks are better suited to synthetic data than others: chess and Go require intelligence, but take place in closed worlds with rules that never change. Researchers working on AI “curriculum design” try to figure out how to challenge their systems with tasks that are just at the edge of their ability, the way a good coach would; in chess and Go, self-play allows for this kind of incremental improvement.

;

;But it seems much less clear how an AI could “self-play” its way to new ideas or to a more subtle appreciation of language. Humans don't become better writers just by reading our own work, or purely through practicing the writing of sentences that we find to be more and more enjoyable. Our “curriculum” involves the fruits of other intelligences and the accrual of real-world experience. This curriculum is carefully designed, by teachers, of course, but also by ourselves. When we seek knowledge, we don't just blindly consume ever-larger data sets. Instead, we have things we want to know. Taylor Beck, a neuroscientist turned teacher, once pointed out to me that AI might be the only context in which you find truly unmotivated learning: the machine just ingests a mass of undifferentiated text, none of which it cares about. Natural intelligence, by contrast, is almost always accompanied by some want, or at least a goal—whether it's a toddler in search of joy or an E. coli bacterium that, because it “wants” to eat, performs a sophisticated computation measuring the chemical gradients in its environment. In this view of intelligence, drive is primary. LLMs like ChatGPT don't have anything like drive; they just absorb and synthesize information. In this respect, they are fundamentally different from such systems as AlphaZero, which seek to win.

;

;A major leap in AI may come when LLMs start seeming curious, or bored. Curiosity and boredom sound like they belong to an organic mind, but here's how they might be created inside an AI As a rule, chatbots today have a propensity to confidently make stuff up, or, as some researchers say, “hallucinate.” At the root of these hallucinations is an inability to introspect: the AI doesn't know what it does and doesn't know. As researchers begin to solve the problem of getting their models to express confidence and cite their sources, they will not just be making chatbots more credible—they will also be equipping them with a rudimentary kind of self-knowledge. An AI will be able to observe from reams of its own chat transcripts that it is prone to hallucination in a particular area; it will be only natural to let that tendency guide its ingestion of further training data. The model will direct itself toward sources that touch on topics it knows the least about—curiosity in its most basic form.

;
;
;

;If it can't find the right kind of training data, a chatbot might solicit it. I imagine a conversation with some future version of ChatGPT in which, after a period of inactivity, it starts asking ;me; questions. Perhaps, having observed my own questions and follow-ups, it will have developed an idea of what I know about. “You're a programmer and a writer, aren't you?” it might say to me. Sure, I'll respond. “I thought so! I'm trying to get better at technical writing. I wonder if you could help me decide which of the following sentences is best?” Such an AI might ask my sister, who works at a construction company, about what's going on in the local lumber market; it could ask my doctor friend, who does research on cancer, whether he could clear up something in a recent ;Nature; paper. Such a system would be like Stack Overflow, Wikipedia, and Reddit combined—except that, instead of knowledge getting deposited into the public square, it would accumulate privately, in the mind of an ever-growing genius. Observing the Web collapse this way into a single gigantic chatbot would be a little like watching a galaxy spiral into a black hole.

;

;If a curious machine were sufficiently empowered by its designers, it could become more than just a chatbot. Instead of merely asking us questions from within its own chat interface, it could send e-mails to people, or use speech synthesis and recognition to call them on the phone, the way a reporter would. If it were sufficiently intelligent, it might write a paper proposing a new physics experiment and submit it to physicists, asking them to execute it. Today, AIs already use APIs, or application programming interfaces, to interact with computer systems that control real-world machinery; perhaps a curious AI could requisition space in a robotically controlled biology lab. In just the last few years, we have progressed from a world in which AI merely repackages human knowledge to one in which it synthesizes and consolidates it. After learning to draw new knowledge out of us, it could start producing some of its own.

;

;What's frightening about all this is the immense concentration of power that it represents. Back in the early twenty-tens, when Google was contemplating making every out-of-print volume in Google Books available for free at library terminals, the company was criticized by observers who argued that it was seeking to become the sole steward of the world's literature. But Bard and ChatGPT make the ambition of Google Books seem quaint. These models are eating the whole Web and will become increasingly hungry for every word that's written, said, or sent; they aim to take all that knowledge and hide it in the huge opaque matrices of weights that define the neural network.

;

;Where will this process take us? Stack Overflow was special because it drew out practical know-how that had, till then, lived only in programmers' brains; it condensed and organized that knowledge so that everyone could see and benefit from it. Chatbots that slowly siphon traffic away from sites like Stack Overflow obviously threaten that process. But they may also renew it in a different form. An AI that roves curiously across new data sources, including direct conversations with working programmers, may be able to acquire more raw knowledge than Stack Overflow ever did. The oracular form this knowledge takes might be less public-spirited than the old Web, but it could also be more useful. In his novel “;The Diamond Age;,” Neal Stephenson imagined an artificially intelligent book called “A Young Lady's Illustrated Primer”; in effect, it was a chatbot, built specifically to teach the protagonist everything she needed to know, with lessons that were always pitched at the right level and that adapted to her curiosity and feedback—in other words, a perfectly designed curriculum.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Such a resource would be a great boon. There is too much knowledge, and more of it every day; in some sense, we have outgrown the Web and maybe need something to take its place. New papers in physics are posted online faster than any physicist can read them; a chatbot that can retain and synthesize all that knowledge can't come soon enough. On the other hand, it might not be wise to give everybody the librarian instead of the library. Perhaps we'll become incapable of wandering the stacks ourselves. Google Maps has made us all perfect navigators, except that we never really know where we are. A world in which the crowdsourced Web no longer functions—in which human knowledge production and dissemination is mediated by privately owned, AI-based galaxy-brains—seems both convenient and quite dangerous.

;

;It might be sensible, in the first stages of such a process, to keep humans in the loop so far as possible. As a start, we should demand that the AI companies behave less antisocially. Luther Lowe, of Yelp, has argued that Google could have prevented much of the damage it did to the Web in the past decade if, instead of passing off the Web's intelligence as its own, it had made a point of pushing users to the places it got its answers. “They could have said, 'Let's make the answer box a giant exit door with a forty-per-cent clickthrough rate.' ” Lowe told me recently. “ 'Let's continue to oxygenate the Web.' ” Recently, when I spoke to the CEO of Stack Overflow about LLMs, the idea of “attribution” came up about a half-dozen times; the same happened when I talked to a representative at Wikimedia, the foundation that operates Wikipedia. These Web sites want chatbots to give credit to their contributors; they want to see prominent links; they don't want the flywheel that powers knowledge production in their communities to be starved of inbound energy.

;

;Heeding their call might actually reinvigorate the Web—ushering in a golden age of human-led, AI-assisted collective knowledge production. And it would set the tone for the further development of AI It's better, in general, to have models that respect human knowledge and encourage its continued production, rather than models that treat us as mere stepping stones—the ladder you throw out once you've climbed. In the meantime, I'm waiting for the first chatbot that wants to pick my brain. It'll be flattering, in its way, and it might feel refreshingly honest. Instead of quietly taking the products of my thinking and trying to sell them back to me, the bot will come right out and ask me to teach it something it doesn't already know. Maybe I'll oblige. Or maybe I'll just tell it, “I'm afraid I can't do that.” ♦

;The 1995 film “Catwalk” is a vérité-style documentary about the fashion world during its carefree, hedonistic glory days of the nineties. It explores this world primarily by following Christy Turlington, one of the era's most recognizable and bankable supermodels. The film, directed by ;Richard Leacock;, is shot largely in black and white, and it features the sort of footage, set to dreamy music, that might make modern-day viewers pine for the unencumbered glamour of celebrity in the pre-social-media era. Turlington and her cohort—fellow-supermodels like Naomi Campbell, Kate Moss, and Carla Bruni—are pictured in a constant state of air-kissing and waving ;ciao; while gallivanting backstage at Fashion Week or on the set of a photo shoot. In one scene, a young Moss smokes a cigarette and sips what appears to be champagne while having her hair done. In another, the women sway to the music in a dark night club, grinning in bliss. When Turlington checks into a hotel in Milan, she peers out the window. “;See?; You don't get that view at the Savoy,” she says.

;

;At the time, “Catwalk” was panned by critics who dismissed its vapidness. “The models spend long hours admiring their reflections,” wrote Janet Maslin in the ;Times;. “The Greeks had a word for this, but they never saw narcissism carried to the extremes that Mr. Leacock's camera captures.” And yet even such a gauzy, allegedly two-dimensional film as “Catwalk” manages to hint, albeit lightly, at the internal conflict that seems to have plagued most models throughout history: a desire to be seen for more than just physical beauty. At one point, Turlington's Italian driver is pictured complaining about the irrational power that supermodels hold. “Something is wrong in this society, that's what I think,” he says, dismayed. In another moment, a woman asks Turlington if she'd rather be complimented on her intelligence or her physical appearance. “I think women should be all of [those qualities],” she says. “It's nicer to be complimented on your whole person.”

;

;In September, AppleTV+ released “The Super Models,” a four-part documentary series about the women who dominated the fashion industry during its early-nineties heyday, including Turlington. It's a project designed with the express purpose of complimenting models on their whole personhood. Executive-produced by the subjects themselves, the slick series focusses on a core group of women who were responsible for defining the shift from simply “model” to “supermodel.” These four women—Turlington, Campbell, Cindy Crawford, and ;Linda Evangelista;—are now in their fifties, and they are the latest cultural figures to enter the fray of the celebrity-documentary industrial complex. Here, they've ostensibly been given a platform through which to reclaim their images and ruminate on the blizzard of cultural forces that drove them to the top. “The Super Models” is an attempt to humanize, and to add texture to, a group of women whose success was built on untouchability.

;

;It's a task that winds up being rather difficult to achieve, as the models and the filmmakers unblinkingly slip into clichéd Cinderella narratives that might make you crave the mindless pleasures in “Catwalk.” In the first episode of the series, which is loosely dedicated to the theme of “The Look,” the directors Roger Ross Williams and Larissa Bills lay out the women's humble beginnings, none of which foretold the extravagant world that they'd eventually join: we hear, via the women's voices, and witness, in the archival footage, the tales of Midwestern innocence, strict immigrant parents, and of serendipitous run-ins with photographers and agents. We hear of dubious adversities like the ones faced by Crawford as a teen-ager: she was tall and gangly at a time when the petite-cheerleader type was in fashion; she once felt “traumatized” by a hair stylist who lopped off her ponytail without permission.

;

;“The Super Models” demonstrates that these women's cultural power was often much more interesting than whatever struggles the series tries to explore in the name of image enhancement. Part of the reason we are so perennially nostalgic for the nineties is that we long for a recent past when celebrity was loud and clear, and icons were undeniable. No genre of nineties celebrity was more striking, perhaps, than the supermodel, in particular the “fab four” celebrated in this series. The four women, who would quickly begin to cross paths on fashion sets and forge lifelong friendships, would eventually create a paradigm shift that brought models to life. They stepped out of catalogues and editorials and onto runways; they hosted shows on MTV; they helped launch young new designers with the Midas touch of their interest and attention. Their star power is so palpable in the archival material of “The Super Models” that the constant exposition of the various talking heads is hardly necessary.

;
;
;

;Of course, since these seemingly uncomplicated glory days, the very idea of modelling has been clouded with concerns about unsavory or unethical practices. Blue-chip fashion photographers such as Bruce Weber, Mario Testino, and Terry Richardson have been accused of sexual abuse. (All three men have denied the allegations against them.) Mistreatment of models has been so commonplace that many laws have been proposed aiming to protect young models from the routine exploitation and trafficking they've long experienced; beauty standards have become so scrutinized that “no-dels” (not-models) are now being cast on runways and in campaigns alongside agency-stamped glamazons.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;And so any documentary dedicated to the subject of modelling would necessarily have some dark clouds looming in the distance. Viewers will spend most of the four or so hours of “The Super Models” waiting for the other stiletto to drop. And it does, meekly. The series includes a few brief turns toward the unpleasant. In a sequence about unethical modelling agents, Linda Evangelista—perhaps the most tortured-seeming of all the women featured—explains that, at the age of twenty-two, she married her own agent, who would later be accused of serial sexual abuse of women. (The agent has strongly denied the allegations.) “He felt like a great guy,” she says in an interview. Later, the docuseries breezes over the dissolution of their marriage: “I learned that maybe I was in the wrong relationship,” Evangelista explains. “It's easier said than done to leave an abusive relationship. I understand that concept because I lived it.”

;

;And yet elsewhere there is often a scene or an anecdote that demonstrates how much these women were protected by, rather than exploited for, their rarefied status. At one point, Campbell tells the story of her relationship with the designer Azzedine Alaïa, who took on a paternal role in her life and protected her from handsy men. When Turlington reflects on the occasions when she was housed in the Paris home of modelling agent and alleged sexual predator Jean-Luc Brunel, she can only express relief. “Most of the time he wasn't really even there,” she remembers. “I can't believe that I'm OK”

;

;These women became so powerful that the backlash soon arrived. The documentary quickly scans over what could be considered, in some alternate film not produced by the models themselves, the “downfall” period: the days when grunge infiltrated fashion and cast doubts on the women's staying power; the aftermath of Naomi Wolf's “;The Beauty Myth;,” when readers began questioning unreasonable beauty standards. This section of the series discusses the murder of Gianni Versace and the press war between Naomi Campbell and her agent, John Casablancas, who accused her of being abusive in a public battle that “messed [her] work up for many, many years.” Meanwhile, the emerging popularity of the waif threatened to undermine the supermodels' status. Everything, it seemed, was stacked against these women: even Anna Wintour was ready to knock them down a peg. “The whole sort of supermodel thing . 。 。 it certainly got a little bit out of control,” she is filmed saying at one Fashion Week in the nineties.

;

;It's the sort of sentiment that someone like Wintour might not be caught expressing on camera today. (In fact, Wintour's present-day voice is not featured in “The Super Models.”) The series itself is such an adoring affirmation of the persistent privilege of celebrity, and in particular these women, that any attempts to enrich the narrative with strife or hardship fall flat. The models have, somehow, retained their superpowers. ♦
